'''Activism''' consists of efforts to promote, impede, or direct [[social change|social]], [[political campaign|political]], [[economics|economic]], or [[Natural environment|environmental]] change. Activism can take a wide range of forms from writing letters to newspapers or politicians, political campaigning, [[economic activism]] such as [[boycott]]s or preferentially patronizing businesses, rallies, [[Demonstration (people)|street marches]], [[strike action|strikes]], [[sit-ins]], and [[hunger strike]]s.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}}
Activists can function in roles as public officials, as in [[judicial activism]]. [[Arthur Schlesinger Jr.]] introduced the term "judicial activism" in a January 1947 [[Fortune (magazine)|''Fortune'' magazine]] article titled "The Supreme Court: 1947."<ref>Keenan Kmiec in a 2004 California Law Review article</ref>
Some activists try to persuade people to change their behavior directly, rather than to persuade governments to change or not to change laws. The [[cooperative movement]] seeks to build new institutions which conform to cooperative principles, and generally does not lobby or protest politically, and clergymen often exhort their parishioners to follow a particular moral code or system.
As with those who engage other activities such as [[singing]] or [[running]], the term may apply broadly to anyone who engages in it even briefly, or be more narrowly limited to those for whom it is a vocation, habit or characteristic practice. In the narrower sense environmental activists that align themselves with [[Earth First]] or Road Protestors would commonly be labelled activists, whilst a local community fighting to stop their park or green being sold off or built on would fit the broader application, due to their using similar means to similarly conservative ends. In short activism is not always an action by Activists.<ref>{{cite web|title=Introduction to Activism|url=http://www.permanentculturenow.com/what-is-activism/|work=Permanent Culture Now|publisher=Permanent Culture Now|accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref>
